resources.string: a 5-minute walk from the British Museum
6-minute walk from Westfield Stratford City shopping centre
5-minute walk from the London Eye and a mile from Big Ben
a Victorian townhouse, this simple hotel in leafy Princes Square is a 6-minute walk from Kensington Palace
Located a block from the Tottenham Court Road tube station and shopping on Oxford Street
On the River Thames next to Tower Bridge, this sprawling modern hotel
the verge of the City of London and the trendy East End, this low-key budget hotel is a 5-minute walk from Tower Hill
A 2-minute walk from the renowned Harrods department store, this high-end hotel in the prestigious Mayfair district
4-minute walk from Victoria railway/underground station, this straightforward conference hotel is within a mile of both Buckingham Palace
Big park with tree-lined jogging paths, a boating lake, kids’ playgrounds and resident fallow deer.
Green oasis for recreation, with swimming ponds, woodland and city views from Parliament Hill.
Huge green space, home to Diana Memorial Fountain, with boating and swimming in the Serpentine lake.
Bridges, wild land and play parks weave a latticework around Londons 2012 Olympic venues.
Modern, glass-clad cafe and sports administrative centre, with pitches and changing rooms.
Expansive walled park, originally a 17th-century hunting ground and still home to hundreds of deer.
Trees and flowers from around the globe in vast gardens with huge greenhouses and Treetop Walkway.
Green space with a lake with daily pelican feeding, a grass-roofed cafe and ceremonial displays.
16-storey Gothic clocktower and national symbol at the Eastern end of the Houses of Parliament.
Visitors can tour the palaces opulent private and state rooms or watch the changing of the guard.
The London Eye is a giant Ferris wheel on the South Bank of the River Thames in London.
87-floor glass skyscraper with a jagged peak, with restaurants, offices, hotel and viewing platform.
Her Majesty s Royal Palace and Fortress of the Tower of London
Panoramic views from high level walkways and behind-the-scenes access to original lifting machinery.
Nelsons Column rises above this iconic squares LED-lit fountains, artworks and lion statues.
Protestant abbey hosting daily services and every English and British coronation since 1066.
